Award.AwardTitle: ARI-MA Improved Detection of Fast Neutrons and Special Nuclear Material (SNM)

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1038691
Vahsen

This award will support the investigation of a new approach to fast neutron detection that utilizes two new detector technologies that the PIs have experience with from experimental particle physics; Gas Electron Multipliers and Silicon Pixel Electronics. These technologies should result in much improved time and position resolution in the readout of gas-filled detectors, so that high rates (up to ~1 MHz/cm2) of both neutrons and charged particles (which may result in false neutron signals) can be measured with much greater precision, and with a lower energy threshold, than with traditional approaches. This is expected to translate into improved ability to locate and identify SNM, as well as significantly reduced rate of false SNM alarms.

The project provides good opportunity for the graduate students and postdoc to obtain training in detector development and characterization. The Postdoc Mentoring Plan is well-organized and appropriate. A scaled up system, if technically feasible, would be very attractive to the DNDO mission.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Normal 0 false false false EN-US X-NONE X-NONE The project "Improved Detection of Fast Neutrons and Special Nuclear Material" investigates how recent technologies developed in experimental particle physics, Gas Electron Multipliers (GEMs) and pixel electronics, can be used to improve the detection of fast neutrons and Special Nuclear Material (SNM). During the first project year we designed and constructed a prototype detector (shown in figures 1 and 2), integrated needed support systems (high/low voltage, data acquisition, gas supply, vacuum), implemented a simulation of the detector, and carried out first commissioning measurements Our simulation work suggests that a Time Projection Chamber (TPC) where the drift charge is read out with Gas Electron Multipliers (GEMs) and pixel electronics should be able to perform precise measurements of nuclear recoils induced by fast neutrons. Using isobutane as the target gas, it should be possible to use this technology to construct a portable (size ~ 50 cm) detector with good (~20%) efficiency for 1-MeV neutrons. Such a detector would have sensitivity to both the direction and energy of incoming neutrons. Since isobutane is flammable, other gases should be explored. Smaller and larger detectors, with lower and higher efficiency, are also possible, depending on the required application. First calibration measurements using the prototype detector system and x-ray sources indicate good detector performance. In the next project period we plan to demonstrate fast neutron detection, and to characterize the detector performance with neutrons in detail. In summary, detectors with GEMs and pixels look promising for improved detection of fast neutrons, and could be important components in systems that search for Special Nuclear Material (SNM). Our simulations suggest that it may be possible to instrument only part of the detector readout area with pixels, by electrically focusing the drift charge after amplification in the GEMs, before it is detected in the pixel electronics. Since pixels are the most expensive ingredient in our detection approach, this would reduce the cost of future detectors, potentially by a large factor. Further refinement of the focusing geometry, and experimental verification of the focusing simulations, are needed.
